bibl.title: Interview with Philip Showalter Hench by a Cuban newspaper, [1952]

div1.p: This interview transcription includes questions posed to Hench by a Cuban newspaper and Hench's answers. Hench expresses appreciation for receiving the Order of Finlay. He explains his thoughts on preserving Camp Lazear and emphasizes the cooperation that took place among people of different countries and different religions in discovering the cause of yellow fever. He also discusses his interest in hormones, particularly cortisone, hydrocortisone, and corticotropin.

div1.head: Interview with Philip Showalter Hench by a Cuban newspaper, [1952]

list.head:
ANSWERS TO NEWSPAPER QUESTIONS
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH, THE MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA

item.p:
QUESTION 1: Have you something to say to the people of Cuba in virtue of the Con-
decoration of the Orden Finlay which you have just received from the hands of the
Minister Dr. Andreu?

ANSWER.- Please see a copy of my expression of appreciation. In addition may I
say that, being a sentimentalist, I am particularly happy to have received this
MURPHY
honor in company with Dr. William P. Murphy whom I admire so much as physician and
man, and whom I have been privileged to know as a friend for many years. Dr. Murphy
is such a quiet and modest gentleman and is one of my country's greatest physician.
The discovery by Drs. Minot and Murphy in Boston about 20 years ago that pernicious
anemia could be controlled by liver extract has saved countless lives and will save
the lives of future millions.

QUESTION 2: What is your opinion regarding the project of the Cuban government to
preserve “Camp Lazear” in Quemados de Marianao?

ANSWER.- I am delighted to learn that the Cuban government is completing plans to
preserve and memorialize the remains of “Camp Lazear” which was part of the old Fin-
ca San José in Quemados. This location occupies a unique place in medical history
and in Cuban-American relationships.

At the Finca San José Dr. Carlos Finlay performed a few of his earliest inoculations
for experimental yellow fever on volunteers of the Jesuist Brotherhood, among them
Padre Urra. Many years later Major Walter Reed, head of the Yellow Fever Board of
the United States Army chose the very same location upon which, with the cordial co-
operation of the owner Dr. Ignacio Rojas, to erect an experimental camp for the
development of yellow fiever in volunteers. This was named “Camp Lazear” in honor of
the heroic martyr Dr. Jesse Lazear who had died as a result of the preliminary ex-
periments.

As the investigations developed so successfully between November 1900 and Feb 1901
Dr. Finlay in great delight visited the camp with Major Reed and his associates, Drs.
Aristides Agramonte and James Carroll.

Here at last was unmistakable proof of the truth of the ideas hold so long and so
tenaciously by Dr. Finlay.

Every human heart meeds inspiration, inspiration from the One on High and inspiration
from one's fellow man. For years physicians like myself have been inspired by the
wonderful story of the conquest of yellow fever.

So conmplicated was the terrible problem of yelIlow fever that no one man, however
great ho might be, could alone solve completely its mystery. Before the world could
accept the far-sighted ideas of Dr. Finlay a score of others had to contribute their brains,
their courage and if necessary their lives. One of those who contributed so much was
that lovable Irish-American-Cuban, Johny Moran, who lived his life here among you un-
til he died last year.

Including first the inspired Dr. Finlay and his devoted associate Claudio Delgado,
these 25 men were 3 Cubans, 1 Englishman, 1 Irishman, 4 Spaniards and 16 Americans.
Some were Catholic, some Protestant, some Hebrews, United in a common cause they pro-
history's
vided one of history's finest examples of humanitarian cooperation and brotherly
love.

That these men lived and accomplished their great service here among you citizens
of Havana and Marianao must be a source of great satisfaction. Thus Camp Lazear
constitutes a place, where, perhaps above all other locations, were united the hopes
and aspirations, the fears, gallantry and courage of this dedicated group of men.
When the plans of Dr. Andreu and his associates for Camp Lazear have been finished, this
place will, I am sure, give great inspiration to those who visit it. Many civilian
and military physicians in my country will feel that they owe your country a debt
of gratitude when the learn of this gracious act of yours.

QUESTION 3: What will be your contribution to the Congress on Nutrition and Vita-
minology now in session in Havana?

ANSWER.- My own interests have been primarily, not in the fields of vitamins and
nutrition, but in the fields of hormones and rheumatic diseases. But many of the
hormones, especially the newest ones, cortisone, hydrocortisone and corticotropin
handle
(ACT5) influence the way our bodies handle most, sugars, starches, fat and enzymes.
Among others Dr. Tom Spies and his colleagues here at the Medical School of Havana
who have been carrying out their important nutritional studies, with the support
of the Fundacion de Investigaciones Médicas, have developed evidence which indicates
the the body's production of the hormone, cortisone, in adequate amounts, may depend
in a large measure upon the available supply of one of the vitamins. So once again
that
we find that all parts of medical science are, in fact, closely related.

This Congress on nutrition affords a splendid opportunity for scientists in various
share
fields to share with each other their views and knowledge. It is particularly
pleasant for a Minnesota “snow-baby” like myself to enjoy this exchange of ideas
under the salubrious, blue skies of Havana. The twenty-second parallel is a fine
location for a medical congress in winter-time!

QUESTION A: Can you tell us briefly what is the position of cortisone and ACTH in
the treatment of rheumatic and arthritic patients?

ANSWER A.- The new hormones cortisone and ACTH do not actually “cure” rheumatic fever
ofor the disabling rheumatoid type of arthritis, in the ordinary sense. Instead they
suppress markedly the inflamatory reactions in these and many other conditions,
thus controlling symptoms.

Those hormones are the most powerful ones ever discovered. Their effects are so
striking and wide-spread that investigators have only begun to learn what we want
much
to know about them. So much remains to be learned, but much important information
in being accumulated rapidly.

Although these hormones still belong as much, if not more, to the physiologists
and clinical investigators, than they do to the general practitioners and rheumatism
specialists they are already most useful, indeed irreplaceable, in the management
of a number of illnesses.

Because in most cases the effects of cortisone and ACTH (corticotropin) do not last
long after their administration has been stopped, the hormones are, up to the present,
more useful and easier to handle in the treatment of acute self-limiting conditions
eyes, severe
such as acute rheumatic fever, certain acute inflamations of the eyes, severe acute
asthma, the acute allergies, and when other severe reactions of hypersensitivity to certain
drugs and toxins develop.

As a result of three years experience my colleagues and I at the Mayo Clinic and
certain other American rheumatologists believe that cortisone and ACTH can be used
safely and with great satisfaction in many cases of chronic
rheumatoid arthritis. Many patients mildly affected need the older, simpler, cheaper
remedice. But for severely or progressively disabled patients, especially those
unresponsive to other measures, the long-continued use of these hormones, especially
of cortisone which can be taken by mouth, in carefully adjusted dosies, constitutes a
very promising form of treatment which may be the one of choice in selected cases.
Success depends on the careful individualized scheme of dosage selected for each
patient, because the appropriate and safe dose varies in different cases, and from
time to time in the same case.

The current policy is to provide as much relief as possible with dosies which do not
produce undesirable “side-effects”.

A new long-acting preparation of ACTH is now available and soon there will be
available greater supplies of the newest hormone, hydrocortisone, which is also anti-
rheumatic and which holds much promise for future usefulness.
